learning_outcomes.description: Critically analyse the relationship between urban design, social and environmental systems, and their impacts, through individual and/or collaborative analysis and propositions.
Deploy a reflexive and research-driven design process.
Integrate contemporary urban strategies, practice and discourse in the design of a complex project at the urban scale, with a focus on contextual, social and environmental system opportunities.

Communicate the technical, experiential, formal and spatial qualities of an urban design proposal across a range of scales and disciplinary contexts, to a best practice standard, using emerging techniques, governance and design strategies to demonstrate urban opportunity and social, economic and environmental enhancement.

assessments.due_date:
Presentation 4/09/2025 9:00 am

Digital Submission 10/09/2025 4:00 pm

Submission: Via Blackboard ULTRA
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Presentation, Product/ Design
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

Building on the insights and strategic planning developed during the 3-Day Workshop, each team shifts focus to the precinct scale to develop an Olympic Legacy Framework (OLF), which culminates in the Olympic Legacy Precinct Plan (OLPP). This plan explores a selected section of Brisbane’s emerging Blue-Green Network, including its surrounding open spaces, public places, and community assets.

The OLF is a spatial and functional design framework that articulates a team’s vision for Olympic Legacy at the precinct scale. It must integrate ‘gold places’—high-quality, inclusive public spaces—with supporting blue-green infrastructure that enhances mobility, water management, ecological performance, and community wellbeing.

Working collaboratively, each team:

• Defines a precinct vision that reflects the Olympic Legacy’s values and long-term aspirations.

• Establishes a set of site-specific design principles and spatial strategies to guide future development.

• Identifies key urban initiatives that support social, environmental, and economic resilience.

• Maps the integration of green and blue systems with public space networks, mobility corridors, and community destinations.

• Investigates local communities to understand their diverse needs, values and aspirations, and proposes ideas for bold legacy initiatives—ranging from projects and policies to targets, programs, and other mechanisms—that foster meaningful community participation and long-term transformation.

Both OLF and OLPP must respond to the unique characteristics of the selected precinct, while also contributing to the broader city-wide Blue-Green Network Map (BGNM) initiated during the workshop. The OLPP serves as the strategic foundation for Assessment Task 3 (A03), where students individually develop a detailed Place Design Toolkit to implement and test the OLPP’s spatial strategies at a finer grain.

A01 is set as a sequence, i.e. it includes tasks in two consecutive weeks:

- Presentation and Review: 4/09/2025, 10 am (video and presentation slide deck to be uploaded to Blackboard Ultra by 9 am)

- Booklet digital submission: 10/09/2025, 4 pm

A01 emphasises collaborative visioning, contextual analysis, and strategic design thinking—laying the groundwork for place-based interventions that can deliver a meaningful and enduring Olympic Legacy. Participation, engagement and contribution to teamwork during the intensive workshop and across the first weeks of the semester (1-6) leading to A01 will be evaluated through a Group Peer Assessment process and may affect the A01 individual grade. If, for whatever reason, you find that your group is not functioning effectively, please contact your Course Coordinator for support.

A01 Deliverables

1. Video documentation (max 5 min) 

2. Presentation slide deck

3. Team oral presentation (20 min team presentation + 10 min feedback)

4. Olympic Legacy Framework booklet (A4 portrait, colour) – including BGNM (finalised), vision, principles, OLPP, and Program of Community Engagement (PCE).

Complex/Authentic assessment using AI and/or MT to support learning: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The School of Architecture, Design and Planning uses Blackboard and Turnitin for assessment submission. Turnitin is accessed through the course Blackboard site. Turnitin also checks for plagiarism or instances where the original work of others is not appropriately acknowledged. Uploaded files must contain readable text and not be rasterised. Students are advised to commence assignment uploads with sufficient amount of time (consider possible technical problems with computers, internet speed, etc). After successfully submitting an assignment through Turnitin, a ‘Submission Complete!’ screen will be displayed. It is the student’s responsibility to check assignment preview and confirm successful submission. If the ‘Submission Complete!’ screen isn’t displayed, the student should regard the submission as unsuccessful. Students should download a copy of the digital receipt as proof they have submitted the assignment. Students who are experiencing upload issues must advise the Course Coordinator immediately by email and should include screenshots and a copy of the assessment for submission. To meet professional accreditation, public engagement and quality assurance obligations, digital copies of all course assessment items must be submitted in addition to any hard copy submission requirements specified in individual Course / Studio Outlines. Any physical models should be photographed and a minimum of two photographs describing the complete and full model must be included in the digital submission.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: The late penalty for this assessment item will be calculated as follows:
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
Slide deck digital submission 16/10/2025 9:00 am

Presentation & Review 16/10/2025 10:00 am
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

In the second phase of the urban design studio, students work individually to develop a Place Design Toolkit (PDT) that supports the implementation of place-based urban interventions proposed in their team’s Olympic Legacy Precinct Plan (OLPP) from Assessment Task 1. The aim is to deepen the understanding of the spatial qualities and character of place envisioned in the OLPP, and to translate these into a set of actionable urban initiatives. These initiatives will serve as design interventions aligned with the OLPP’s vision, principles, and development strategies. Each student selects a specific area within their team’s precinct plan to focus on, ensuring that the team collectively produces a comprehensive and complementary suite of guidelines.

Within their chosen area, individually students must:

• Advance the spatial strategies established in A01.

• Provide a detailed analysis of place-specific qualities and character.

• Test and refine design ideas for a high-quality network of public spaces and blue-green infrastructure.

• Design and test place-based engagement strategies tailored to specific local contexts.

The Place Design Toolkit should propose interventions that promote social and environmental wellbeing, with a focus on:

• Expanding green and open spaces.

• Enhancing accessibility and comfort for outdoor leisure.

• Supporting active travel networks.

• Integrating nature-based water management solutions.

• Mitigating urban heat island effects.

This assignment challenges students to bridge strategic planning with detailed design thinking, enabling the delivery of a resilient and inclusive Olympic Legacy at the local scale.

A02 requires students to develop a draft of their final A03 submission for formative feedback. Minimum submission requirements are included in the A02 Outline (Blackboard Ultra).

A02 Deliverables

  1. Oral presentation (10 min presentation + 5 min feedback)
  2. Presentation slide deck (to be uploaded to Blackboard Ultra by 9 am)

Complex/Authentic assessment using AI and/or MT to support learning: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The School of Architecture, Design and Planning uses Blackboard and Turnitin for assessment submission. Turnitin is accessed through the course Blackboard site. Turnitin also checks for plagiarism or instances where the original work of others is not appropriately acknowledged. Uploaded files must contain readable text and not be rasterised. Students are advised to commence assignment uploads with sufficient amount of time (consider possible technical problems with computers, internet speed, etc). After successfully submitting an assignment through Turnitin, a ‘Submission Complete!’ screen will be displayed. It is the student’s responsibility to check assignment preview and confirm successful submission. If the ‘Submission Complete!’ screen isn’t displayed, the student should regard the submission as unsuccessful. Students should download a copy of the digital receipt as proof they have submitted the assignment. Students who are experiencing upload issues must advise the Course Coordinator immediately by email and should include screenshots and a copy of the assessment for submission. To meet professional accreditation, public engagement and quality assurance obligations, digital copies of all course assessment items must be submitted in addition to any hard copy submission requirements specified in individual Course / Studio Outlines. Any physical models should be photographed and a minimum of two photographs describing the complete and full model must be included in the digital submission.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(21 Jul - 26 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture

Week 1 (24-26/7) - Intensive Design Studio - City Scale

Day 1 - Understanding urban systems (Paola & Cathryn)

AM: Project introduction + teamwork; PM: City thinking - Shaping Brisbane

Day 2 - Big Ideas for 2032 Brisbane (guest lectures)

AM: Green Pathways Gold Places + Visioning for the Brisbane 2032 Olympic Paralympic Games

Day 3 - Understanding Olympic Legacy - the challenges and opportunities

AM: What is Olympic Legacy? (Paola & Cathryn)

Week 3 (7/8) - Olympic Legacy Framework: vision, principles and actors

AM: Future South Bank Master Plan (guest lecture)

Week 4 (14/8)- Olympic Legacy: Environmental resilience (mapping blue-green challenges and opportunities)

AM: Water Sensitive Urban Design - Theory and case studies (guest lecture)

Week 6 (28/08) - Olympic Legacy Precinct Plan

AM: Olympic site design for shaping urban change (Paola & Cathryn)

Week 8 (11/9)– Place Design Toolkit-Understanding community and places

AM: Overview of A02 and A03 (Paola & Cathryn)

Week 9 (18/9)– Place Design Toolkit

AM: What is a Place Design Toolkit? Exploring the elements of effective design guidelines (Paola & Cathryn)

Week 13 (23/10)- Place Design Toolkit: finalisation and presentation plan

AM: Communicate with impact (guest lecture)


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04

Exploring the elements of effective design guidelines (Paola & Cathryn) Week 13 (23/10) - Place Design Toolkit: finalisation and presentation plan AM: Communicate with impact (guest lecture)

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 14(21 Jul - 02 Nov)
learning_activities.topic:
Design Studio

Week 1 (24-26/7) - Intensive Design Studio - City Scale (teamwork)

Day 1 - Team building; Urban analysis (SWOT) + Roundtable (challenges and opportunity for change at city scale)

Day 2 - Blue-green Network Map – contextual research and mapping

Day 3 - Learning from the Olympics - case study analysis

Week 2 (31/7) - Week 2 - Blue-green Network Map and ideas (teamwork)

- Sharing the Blue-green Network Map

- Case study presentation: Olympic Legacy strategies (identified strategies for Brisbane 2032)

- Team building and formation + Precinct selection

- Precinct structural layers: theory, research, mapping

Week 3 (7/8) - Olympic Legacy Framework: Guiding change

- Workshop: Developing visions and urban design strategies workshop (teamwork)

Week 4 (14/8) - Olympic Legacy: Environmental resilience (mapping blue-green challenges and opportunities)

- Workshop: Precinct's blue-green infrastructure for environmental resilience (teamwork)

Week 6 (28/8) - Olympic Legacy Precinct Plan: Spatial strategies

- Workshop: Spatial strategies towards OLPP

Week 7 (4/9) - Olympic Legacy Framework (A01): Presentation

Week 8 (11/9) - Mapping ‘golden places’ within the OLPP (teamwork)

- Team discussion, mapping, presentation to other teams, peer feedback and individual selection of an urban initiative

Week 9 (18/9) - What is the “Place Design Toolkit”?

- Understanding urban design guidelines (examples). Searching, sharing, discussing

Week 10 (25/9) - Developing the Place Design Toolkit: Testing ideas

- Team and individual tutoring section and peer feedback

Week 11 (9/10) - Place Design Toolkit: Draft

- Team and individual tutoring section and peer feedback

Week 12 (16/10) - Place Design Toolkit (A02): Presentation for formative feedback

- Industry and peer feedback

Week 13 (23/10) - Place Design Toolkit: Communication plan

- Team and individual tutoring section and peer feedback

Week 14 (30/10) - Place Design Toolkit (A03): Final presentation


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Excursion

Week 5 - Legacy – Social resilience (mapping communities and their needs)

- Visit to Ipswich Central - Council and community led regeneration project

- Workshop: Strategies for community resilience (precinct scale)



Learning outcomes: L03
